name: Self-Awareness
description: The ability to accurately recognize your emotions, thoughts, and values and understand how they influence your behavior. It involves recognizing your strengths and limitations with a well-grounded sense of confidence and optimism.
examples: Identifying when you're feeling anxious before a test.
Recognizing your strength in solving math problems.
Admitting when you need help or support.

name: Self-Management
description: The ability to regulate your emotions, thoughts, and behaviors in different situations. This includes managing stress, controlling impulses, motivating yourself, and setting and working toward personal goals.
examples: Practicing deep breathing to stay calm during a conflict.
Setting a study schedule and sticking to it.

name: Social Awareness
description: The ability to take the perspective of and empathize with others, including those from diverse backgrounds and cultures. It also involves understanding social and ethical norms for behavior and recognizing family, school, and community resources and supports.
examples: Understanding how a classmate might feel left out.
Respecting othersâ€™ opinions even if you disagree.
Recognizing when a friend is uncomfortable and offering help.

name: Empathy
description: The ability to understand and share the feelings of another. Empathy is crucial in building strong relationships and fostering a supportive environment. It allows individuals to connect on a deeper level, promoting compassion and understanding.
examples: Listening actively to a friend's problems and offering support.
Volunteering at a local shelter to help those in need.
Practicing mindfulness to better understand your own emotions.

name: Relationship Skills
description: The ability to establish and maintain healthy and rewarding relationships with diverse individuals and groups. This includes communicating clearly, listening well, cooperating with others, resisting inappropriate social pressure, negotiating conflict constructively, and seeking and offering help when needed.
examples: Working together with classmates on a group project.
Resolving a disagreement by calmly discussing both sides.
Encouraging a friend who is feeling down.

name: Responsible Decision-Making
description: The ability to make caring and constructive choices about personal behavior and social interactions based on ethical standards, safety, and social norms. It includes evaluating consequences and considering the well-being of oneself and others.
examples: Deciding not to join in teasing someone even if others are doing it.
Thinking through the pros and cons before making a big decision.
Reporting unsafe behavior to a trusted adult.
